Polymer blends yield carbon materials with superior performances for supercapacitor applications since blending can lead to controlled and fine pore architectures. In this study, a supercapacitor electrode material derived from an immiscible polymer blend comprising polyacrylonitrile (PAN) and polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) was investigated. PAN was used as the carbonizing polymer while PMMA was used as the sacrificial polymer. The polymer blend solns. in DMF were electrospun to obtain freestanding nanofiber mats. The resulting mat was carbonized and activated by CO2 at 1000 °C to obtain porous carbon nanofibers (CNFs), as PAN converts to carbon and the sacrificial polymer decomps. creating pores. We demonstrated that the pore sizes can be tuned by varying the amt. of PMMA loading in the blend compns. PAN : PMMA (95 : 5), was found to be the optimum blend compn., affording the highest surface area of 2419 m2 g-1, higher degree of graphitization, higher carbon yield and lower charge transfer resistance among the blend compns. studied. Furthermore, the PAN : PMMA (95 : 5) CNFs showed the highest capacitance of 140 F g-1 and energy densities of 67 W h kg-1 at 3.5 V and 101 W h kg-1 at 4 V in an ionic electrolyte (EMITFSI) and also showed good cycling stability with 85% capacitance retention after 1000 cycles.

We report a facile method for prepn. of extremely high surface area and uniformly porous carbon nanofibers for supercapacitors. Blends of polyacrylonitrile and sacrificial Nafion at different compns. have been electrospun into nonwoven nanofiber mats with diams. in the range of 200-400 nm. Electrospun nanofiber mats are then subjected to carbonization to obtain porous carbon nanofibers as polyacrylonitrile converts to carbon and Nafion decomps. out creating intra-fiber pores. Resultant porous carbon nanofibers exhibit sp. surface area of up to 1600 m2/g with a large fraction of mesopores (2-4 nm). No addnl. chem. or phys. activation process was used. We demonstrate the tunability of the pore sizes within carbon nanofibers by varying the amt. of Nafion. The nonwoven fiber mats of porous carbon nanofibers are studied as free-standing electrode materials for supercapacitors eliminating the need for polymeric binding agents. Electrochem. measurements showed large specific gravimetric and volumetric capacitances of up to 210 F/g and 60 F/cm3 in 1M H2SO4 at a high cyclic voltammetry scan rate of 100 mV/s due to the large fraction of mesopores. These materials retain 75% performance at a large c.d. of 20 A/g indicating excellent power handling capability.

The relationships between the compatibility in binary polymer blends and the pore sizes of carbon nanofibers (CNFs) prepd. from the blends were investigated. Compatibility was detd. by the difference between the soly. parameters of each polymer in the polymer blends. Porous CNFs were prepd. by an electrospinning and carbonization process using binary polymer blends, consisting of polyacrylonitrile (PAN) as the carbonizing polymer and poly(acrylic acid) (PAA), poly(ethylene glycol), poly(Me methacrylate) or polystyrene (PS) as the pyrolyzing polymer. The pore size of the CNFs increased with increasing difference in soly. parameter. The CNFs prepd. using the PAN/PAA blend, which had the smallest soly. parameter difference, exhibited a pore size of 1.66 nm compared to 18.24 nm for the CNFs prepd. using the PAN/PS blend. The prepd. CNF webs with controlled meso-sized pores showed a stable cycle performance in cyclic voltammetry measurements and improved impedance characteristics. This method focusing on the compatibility in polymer blends was simple to apply and effective for controlling the pore sizes and surface area of CNFs for application as electrode materials in energy storage systems.

The presence site-selective interaction between the conjugated PmAP chain and the π-bonded surface of c-MWCNT was confirmed by Fourier transform IR (FT-IR) and Raman spectroscopy. The morphol. anal. of the nanocomposite showed the formation of PmAP coating (thickness ∼100 nm) on the CNT surfaces. The X-ray and electron diffraction patterns of the nanocomposites indicated the cryst. nature of the PmAP matrix. The nanocomposite with small quantity of c-MWCNT (2 wt%) was found to have sensing response about 114% and 96% higher than that of pure PmAP for methanol and ethanol vapor (90 ppm). This dramatic improvement of sensing performance might be attributed to the favorable interactions of c-MWCNTs with conjugated PmAP chains that subsequently generate a pathway for possible H-bonding/dipole interaction with the alc. mols. The nanocomposite sensor also exhibits distinct features of the response curves and response values for different aliph. alcs., which could be used as a basis for the selective detection of these pollutant vapors. The UV-vis and FT-IR analyses were used to explain the sensing mechanism.

Capacitive deionization (CDI) is strongly recommended as an environmentally friendly and economical technique for removing salts from saline water. Highly efficient hollow C nanofiber electrodes for capacitive deionization were prepd. using coaxial electrospinning of poly(Me methacrylate) (core) and poly(acrylonitrile) (shell) polymer solns., followed by oxidative stabilization and then carbonization. The morphol., pore structure and electrochem. performance were characterized by SEM and TEM, N adsorption-desorption isotherms, and cyclic voltammetry, resp. The synthesized hollow C nanofibers had a specific capacitance of 222.3 F/g, which is ∼4 times higher than the corresponding value for solid C nanofibers (63 F/g). The surface area of the hollow nanofibers (186 m2/g) was 10 times greater compared to the surface area of solid C nanofibers (17.7 m2/g). The salt electrosorption capacity of the modified C nanofibers was greatly enhanced; the hollow nanofibers exhibited an excellent desalination performance (∼86%) and a better cycling ability. These properties are attributed to the hollow structure. Overall, the proposed modification to C nanofibers makes them adequate not only for use as promising electrodes for the CDI process but also for any application requiring carbonaceous materials with a high sp. surface area.

Sulfur is a promising cathode material for lithium batteries as it possesses high theor. specific capacity and low cost. However, the practical electrochem. performance of lithium-sulfur batteries needs to be improved. In this work, a carbon nanofibers-carbon matrix-sulfur composite is synthesized to improve the electrochem. properties of lithium-sulfur batteries. The carbon matrix-sulfur composite is fabricated by deoxidizing the carbon precursor-sulfur composite. Morphol., structure and electrochem. properties of materials have been characterized and tested. Results show that the carbon matrix-sulfur composite envelops carbon nanofibers and sulfur is evenly distributed in the carbon nanofibers-carbon matrix-sulfur composite. In a carbon matrix-sulfur composite, sulfur chem. bonds with the carbon matrix. The chem. bonds form in the process of deoxidizing the carbon precursor-sulfur composite. In a carbon nanofibers-sulfur mixt., sulfur is dispersed on carbon nanofibers. In comparison with a carbon nanofibers-sulfur mixt. electrode, the carbon nanofibers-carbon matrix-sulfur composite electrode exhibits higher discharge capacity and cycle stability. The better electrochem. performance is ascribed to the restriction for dissoln. of lithium polysulfides through the adsorbability of the carbon matrix.

Highly flexible porous carbon nanofibers (P-CNFs) were fabricated by electrospining technique combining with metal ion-assistant acid corrosion process. The resultant fibers display high cond. and outstanding mech. flexibility, whereas little change in their resistance can be obsd. under repeatedly bending, even to 180°. Further results indicate that the improved flexibility of P-CNFs can be due to the high graphitization degree caused by Co ions. In view of electrode materials for high-performance supercapacitors, this type of porous nanostructure and high graphitization degree could synergistically facilitate the electrolyte ion diffusion and electron transportation. In the three electrodes testing system, the resultant P-CNFs electrodes can exhibit a specific capacitance of 104.5 F g-1 (0.2 A g-1), high rate capability (remain 56.5% at 10 A g-1), and capacitance retention of ∼94% after 2000 cycles. Furthermore, the assembled sym. supercapacitors showed a high flexibility and can deliver an energy d. of 3.22 Wh kg-1 at power d. of 600 W kg-1. This work might open a way to improve the mech. properties of carbon fibers and suggests that this type of freestanding P-CNFs be used as effective electrode materials for flexible all-carbon supercapacitors.

Controlled synthesis of carbon nanomaterials with particular shape, compn., architecture, and doping is important, yet still a great challenge, for enhancing supercapacitor performance with high energy and power densities and long lifetime. Herein, we demonstrate an interesting process combining surfactantless and templateless wet chem. and post-high-temp. carbonization strategies for obtaining a new class of nitrogen-doped hierarchical porous carbon nanowhisker ensembles supported on carbon nanofibers (NHCNs) with tunable micropores and a nitrogen-doping level for high-performance supercapacitors. Under the optimal pore size and nitrogen doping controlled by carbonization at different temps., the NHCNs (NHCNs-750) carbonized at 750° shows an optimal specific capacitance of 210.1 F g-1 at 5 mV/s, which is much higher than other one-dimensional carbon nanostructures (e.g., pure carbon nanofibers (2.6 F g-1) and carbon nanotubes (10.6 F g-1) at 5 mV/s). NHCNs-750 also showed good rate capability of 78.5% and 75.2% capacitance retention at 100 mV/s and 200 mV/s, resp., and excellent cycling stability of 96.2% capacitance retention after 3000 cycles. Furthermore, we found that the specific capacitance of NHCNs can be further increased to 254.3 F g-1 by a KOH-assisted high-temp. process. The present work opens a new route to design advanced 1D hierarchical carbon nanomaterials with tunable pores and nitrogen doping for enhancing energy storage and conversion applications.

Carbon-based materials are the most common and important supercapacitor electrode materials, and have been attracting much attention for researchers. Although much work has focused on increasing the gravimetric capacitance of carbon materials, it is highly needed to obtain high volumetric capacitance for real compact device application. Therefore, a finely tuned carbon material structure with both optimal gravimetric and volumetric capacitances has been becoming a considerable challenge. In this work, we synthesized free-standing boron and oxygen co-doped carbon nanofiber (BO-CNF) films for the first time. Both high gravimetric and volumetric capacitances (192.8 F g-1 and 179.3 F cm-3 at 1 A g-1) can be obtained by an optimized design with regulating the heteroatom content and packing d. Meanwhile, the BO-CNF film with a relatively high packing d. exhibits an excellent rate capability (78.5% capacitance retention from 1 to 100 A g-1), which is due to the formation of continuous electrolyte ion diffusion network as well as good elec. cond. Such BO-CNF film provides an excellent platform for depositing polyaniline active materials and the boron dopant can be recycled to reduce the cost for the possibly scalable application.

S has a high sp. capacity of 1673 mA-h/g as Li battery cathodes, but its rapid capacity fading due to polysulfides dissoln. presents a challenge for practical applications. The authors report a hollow C nanofiber-encapsulated S cathode for effective trapping of polysulfides and demonstrate exptl. high sp. capacity and excellent electrochem. cycling of the cells. The hollow C nanofiber arrays were fabricated using anodic Al oxide (AAO) templates, through thermal carbonization of polystyrene. The AAO template also facilitates S infusion into the hollow fibers and prevents S from coating onto the exterior C wall. The high aspect ratio of the C nanofibers provides an ideal structure for trapping polysulfides, and the thin C wall allows rapid transport of Li ions. The small dimension of these nanofibers provides a large surface area per unit mass for Li2S deposition during cycling and reduces pulverization of electrode materials due to volumetric expansion. A high specific capacity of ∼730 mA-h/g was obsd. at C/5 rate after 150 cycles of charge/discharge. The introduction of LiNO3 additive to the electrolyte was shown to improve the Coulombic efficiency to over 99% at C/5. The hollow C nanofiber-encapsulated S structure could be a promising cathode design for rechargeable Li/S batteries with high sp. energy.

Carbon-coated Si nanocomposites were produced by spray pyrolysis and these reversibly store lithium with both a high capacity of 1489 mA-h/g and a coulombic efficiency >99.5%, even after 20 cycles. The spray pyrolysis method used is instantaneous, versatile, inexpensive, industrially oriented, and can be operated at 150-1400°C. The sp. capacity of Si in the composite electrode was calcd. to be 3257 mA-h/g which is 77% of the theor. value. This nanocomposite anode material is suitable for Li-ion batteries.

span.span: Nitrogen-doped hierarchical porous carbon materials prepared from meta-aminophenol formaldehyde resin for supercapacitor with high rate performance

Nitrogen-doped hierarchical porous carbon materials prepared from meta-aminophenol formaldehyde resin for supercapacitor with high rate performance
Zhou, Jin; Zhang, Zhongshen; Xing, Wei; Yu, Jing; Han, Guoxing; Si, Weijiang; Zhuo, Shuping
Electrochimica Acta
(

),

(

68-75

(
Elsevier Ltd.
)
N-doped hierarchical porous C materials (NHPCs) were prepd. by a two-step method combined of a hard template process and KOH-activation treatment. Low cost and large-scale com. nano-SiO2 were used as a hard template. The hierarchical porosity, structure and N-doped surface chem. properties are proved by a varies of means, such as SEM, transition electron microscopy, N2 sorption, Raman spectroscopy, x-ray diffraction and XPS. When the prepd. NHPCs materials were used as the electrode materials for supercapacitors in KOH electrolyte, they exhibit very high specific capacitance, good power capability and excellent cyclic stability. NHPC-800 C shows a high capacitance of 114.0 F g-1 at the c.d. of 40 A g-1, responding to a high energy and power densities of 4.0 Wh kg-1 and 10,000 W kg-1, and a very short drain time of 1.4 s. The excellent capacitive performance may be due to the synergistic effect of the hierarchical porosity, high effective surface area and heteroatom doping, resulting in both electrochem. double layer and faradaic capacitance contributions.

Nitrogen-doped hierarchical porous carbon as an efficient electrode material for supercapacitors
Wang, Guiqiang; Zhang, Juan; Kuang, Shuai; Zhou, Jin; Xing, Wei; Zhuo, Shuping
Electrochimica Acta
(
2015
),
153
(

273-279
CODEN:
ELCAAV
; ISSN:
0013-4686
.
(
Elsevier Ltd.
)
Nitrogen-doped hierarchical porous carbon (NHPC) was prepd. by a combination of self-assembly and chem. activation and explored as an electrode materials for supercapacitors. Pore structure anal. showed that the pristine mesopores were basically preserved during activation, while the micropores were generated within the mesopore wall in large quantities. Cyclic voltammetry and galvanostatic charge/discharge measurements showed that the as-prepd. NHPC exhibited a high specific capacitance of up to 257.8 F/g, excellent rate capability and good cycling durability in 6M KOH electrolyte. The enhanced capacitive performance of NHPC can be attributed to the following three points: (a) the generated micropores play a most important role in the formation of elec. double layer capacitance; (b) the hierarchical porous structure favors the fast diffusion of the electrolyte; (c) the nitrogen-contg. functionalities generate extra pseudocapacitance and improve the wettability of the materials to the KOH electrolyte.
